body: This happens because `last` relies on `reverse_order!` [here](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/d57c5073a63851f887668e8384f963b99d4e0d62/activerecord/lib/active_record/relation/finder_methods.rb#L206). Let me know what the expected behaviour should be and I'd be happy to send a PR.

I'd say the correct behavior would be for `first` to raise if there isn't an implicit order.

Because right now it relies on whatever order the database returns which is often somewhat random and is a recipe for bugs.

It would be good to improve the error message to make it easier to action, e.g. include model name, how to set an implicit order column, etc.

I just realized that another 'bug' is that `reverse_order` [doesn't respect `implicit_order_column`](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/7845576df0fb68ff38f9ca754fca457a8e6758a3/activerecord/lib/active_record/relation/query_methods.rb#L2011-L2015). So if you don't have a pk but do have an order column, something like `Post.all.reverse_order.first` raises `ActiveRecord::IrreversibleOrderError` despite `Post.all.first` returning the expected result. I'll tackle that as well.

issue.title: Ensure `#reverse_order` respects `implicit_order_column`
issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing to Rails!

Please do not make *Draft* pull requests, as they still send
notifications to everyone watching the Rails repo.

Create a pull request when it is ready for review and feedback
from the Rails team :).

If your pull request affects documentation or any non-code
changes, guidelines for those changes are [available
here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#contributing-to-the-rails-documentation)

About this template

The following template aims to help contributors write a good description for their pull requests.
We'd like you to provide a description of the changes in your pull request (i.e. bugs fixed or features added), the motivation behind the changes, and complete the checklist below before opening a pull request.

Feel free to discard it if you need to (e.g. when you just fix a typo). -->

### Motivation / Background

<!--
Describe why this Pull Request needs to be merged. What bug have you fixed? What feature have you added? Why is it important?
If you are fixing a specific issue, include "Fixes #ISSUE" (replace with the issue number, remove the quotes) and the issue will be linked to this PR.
-->

Addresses https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/54591#issuecomment-2677869549

### Detail

Updates `ActiveRecord::QueryMethods#reverse_sql_order` ~to utilize `_order_columns` similar to `ActiveRecord::FinderMethods#ordered_relation`~ to account for `implicit_order_column`. This ensures that:
1. ~`#reverse_sql_order` is now consistent with `#ordered_relation`.~
2. `#reverse_order` now respects `implicit_order_column` ~as well as `query_constraints`~, and not just `primary_key`.
3. ~We can now simply use `#reverse_order` in `#last` instead of having to order and then reverse the order (this has comprehensive test coverage)~

Edits were made after https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/54607#issuecomment-2678291542

### Checklist

Before submitting the PR make sure the following are checked:

* [x] This Pull Request is related to one change. Unrelated changes should be opened in separate PRs.
* [x] Commit message has a detailed description of what changed and why. If this PR fixes a related issue include it in the commit message. Ex: `[Fix #issue-number]`
* [x] Tests are added or updated if you fix a bug or add a feature.
* [x] CHANGELOG files are updated for the changed libraries if there is a behavior change or additional feature. Minor bug fixes and documentation changes should not be included.

body:
> I just realized that another 'bug' is that `reverse_order` [doesn't respect `implicit_order_column`](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/7845576df0fb68ff38f9ca754fca457a8e6758a3/activerecord/lib/active_record/relation/query_methods.rb#L2011-L2015). So if you don't have a pk but do have an order column, something like `Post.all.reverse_order.first` raises `ActiveRecord::IrreversibleOrderError` despite `Post.all.first` returning the expected result. I'll tackle that as well.

PR for this one: https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/54607

issue.title: [Fix #54591] Raise an error in order dependent finder methods when the model has no order columns
issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing to Rails!

Please do not make *Draft* pull requests, as they still send
notifications to everyone watching the Rails repo.

Create a pull request when it is ready for review and feedback
from the Rails team :).

If your pull request affects documentation or any non-code
changes, guidelines for those changes are [available
here](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/contributing_to_ruby_on_rails.html#contributing-to-the-rails-documentation)

About this template

The following template aims to help contributors write a good description for their pull requests.
We'd like you to provide a description of the changes in your pull request (i.e. bugs fixed or features added), the motivation behind the changes, and complete the checklist below before opening a pull request.

Feel free to discard it if you need to (e.g. when you just fix a typo). -->

### Motivation / Background

<!--
Describe why this Pull Request needs to be merged. What bug have you fixed? What feature have you added? Why is it important?
If you are fixing a specific issue, include "Fixes #ISSUE" (replace with the issue number, remove the quotes) and the issue will be linked to this PR.
-->

Fixes https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/54591
Follow-up to https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/54607

### Detail

1. Adds a new error `ActiveRecord::MissingRequiredOrderError` which gets raised in `ActiveRecord::FinderMethods#ordered_relation` (used by `#last` and and all `find_nth*` methods) when there are no `order_values` and no order columns to be used for the default order.
2. Updates a similar case where `ActiveRecord::IrreversibleOrderError` is raised in `ActiveRecord::QueryMethods#reverse_sql_order` to have a message consistent with this new error.

cc @byroot

### Checklist

Before submitting the PR make sure the following are checked:

* [x] This Pull Request is related to one change. Unrelated changes should be opened in separate PRs.
* [x] Commit message has a detailed description of what changed and why. If this PR fixes a related issue include it in the commit message. Ex: `[Fix #issue-number]`
* [x] Tests are added or updated if you fix a bug or add a feature.
* [x] CHANGELOG files are updated for the changed libraries if there is a behavior change or additional feature. Minor bug fixes and documentation changes should not be included.

body:
Thank you @joshuay03 for working on this, Would it be helpful to add the info as NOTE - if implcit_order_column or primary key or query constraint is missing it will raise an error  in the [guide](https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/active_record_querying.html#retrieving-a-single-object).

If this change makes sense, I'd be happy to open a pull request. Thank you.

> Thank you [@joshuay03](https://github.com/joshuay03?rgh-link-date=2025-02-24T14%3A19%3A47.000Z) for working on this, Would it be helpful to add the info as NOTE - if implcit_order_column or primary key or query constraint is missing it will raise an error in the guide. I'll delegate to @byroot but here are my thoughts - By guide if you mean the API docs I think it's tricky cause this actually affects a few other methods as well e.g. `#second_to_last`, `#fourth` etc., and I don't know if it makes sense to mention this in the docs for each. If by guide you meant the actual guides I don't know if this is appropriate to mention there, as it's somewhat of an implementation detail, but there seem to be some cases where errors are mentioned. I'll also note that I've included this information in the error message in my PR, so it should be clear to users why we're raising.
